exercise.name: guessSd
exercise.description: Guess the standard deviation from a normal density
exercise.comment: A normal pdf is shown and its standard deviation must be guessed by eye.
exercise.variable: Name for variable
Axis for dot plot
Used to generate the mean and SD for the normal distn
Actually generated by jointMeanSD

template.question: The normal distribution below has mean #mu# = #mean(:)#. Guess its standard deviation, #sigma#.

variation.question: The heights of a particular kind of flowering plant have the normal distribution shown below.\\nThis distribution has mean #mu# = #mean(:)# cm. Guess the standard deviation of the heights, #sigma#.

variation.longName: Annual rainfall in an African town
variation.question: The annual rainfall in an African town has a normal distribution with mean #mu# = #mean(:)# mm.\\nThe pdf of the distribution is shown below. Guess its standard deviation, #sigma#.

Weekly household expenditure on food in a country has a distribution that is approximately normal with the shape shown below.\\nThe mean expenditure is #mu# = $#mean(:)#. Guess its standard deviation, #sigma#.

exercise.name: sketchDistn
exercise.description: Sketch normal distribution's pdf from its mean and sd
exercise.comment: A normal distribution's mean and standard deviation are given. Two arrows on a normal pdf must be dragged to adjust its location and spread to roughly match these values.\\nIf the option for multiple axes is chosen, the question becomes a little harder since a suitable axis for the distribution must be selected first.
exercise.option: Shows a pop-up menu of axes from which a suitable one must be selected.
exercise.variable: Name for variable
List of axes from which one is picked for the normal distribution
Names for the different axes, only used when there is a pop-up menu to choose the best axis to display the distn.
Index of axis from which normal distribution is generated
Used to generate the mean and SD for the normal distribution
Actually generated by jointMeanSD
Actually generated by jointMeanSD

template.question: A normal distribution has mean #mu# = #mean(:)# and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd(:)#. Sketch it.

variation.question: Annual rainfall in an African town is approximately normally distributed with mean #mu# = #mean(:)# mm and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd(:)# mm.\\nSketch this normal distribution.

variation.longName: Max daily temperature in a city
variation.question: The maximum daily temperature in an Asian city during March is approximately normal with mean #mu# = #mean(:)##degrees#C and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd(:)##degrees#C.\\nSketch this normal distribution.

variation.longName: Monthly wind run in a city
variation.question: The monthly wind run in a New Zealand city in October is approximately normal with mean #mu# = #mean(:)# km and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd(:)# km.\\nSketch this normal distribution.

exercise.name: pByDraggingOverPdf
exercise.description: Find a normal probability or expected count (drag over its pdf)
exercise.comment: A normal pdf is displayed and the probability of being less than a value (or greater than it, between 2 values or not between 2 values) is requested. (Some variations ask for the expected number in a sample of size n instead of the probability.)\\nThe relevant area can be found roughly by dragging on the pdf or, more accurately, by typing interval end-points into text edit boxes.
exercise.option: Displays a simple template to help evaluate an expected count (not needed to find probabilities)
exercise.variable: Name for variable

variable.name: intervalType
variable.type: int_choice(Less than cutoff#Greater than cutoff#Between two cutoffs#Outside two cutoffs)

exercise.variable: Defines the minimum and maximum cutoff values (or the z-scores between which they ar randomly generated)
Template for the maximum possible x-value
Variations can either request a probability of the expected number in n values
If the question is about the expected number in an interval, this should be positive. Otherwise leave it blank.

template.question: A normal distribution has mean #mu# = #mean(10)# and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd(3)#. What is the probability of getting a value #cut-offs(-3:3:1)#?

variation.question: The maximum daily temperature in a city in January is approximately normally distributed with mean #mu# = #mean[index](10,15,20,25)##degrees#C and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](3,4,5)##degrees#C.\\nWhat is the probability that the maximum temperature will be #cut-offs(-3:3:1)##degrees#C in one day?

The weight of the seeds of one species of tree has a normal distribution with mean #mu# = #mean[index](18,19,20,21)# grams and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](1,1.5,2)# grams.\\nWhat is the probability that one seed from this type of tree has weight #cut-offs(-3:3:1)# grams?

The maximum daily temperature in a city in January is approximately normally distributed with mean #mu# = #mean[index](10,15,20,25)##degrees#C and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](3,4,5)##degrees#C.\\nIn how many days out of #count[](5,10,15,20,25,30)# would you expect the maximum temperature to be #cut-offs(-3:3:1)##degrees#C?

The weight of the seeds of one species of tree has a normal distribution with mean #mu# = #mean[index](18,19,20,21)# grams and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](1,1.5,2)# grams.\\nIn a sample of #count[](5,10,15,20,25,30)# seeds, how many would you expect to have weight #cut-offs(-3:3:1)# grams?

exercise.name: pByDraggingOverN(0,1)
exercise.description: Find a normal probability using z-scores and dragging over N(0,1) pdf
exercise.comment: A question asks for a probability about a normal distribution (or the expected count in a sample of n for some variations).\\nThe end-point(s) of the interval must be translated into z-scores first. The relevant area under a N(0,1) pdf between the z-scores can be found roughly by dragging on a pdf or, more accurately, by typing the z-scores into text edit boxes.
exercise.option: Displays a simple template to help evaluate an expected count (not needed to find probabilities)

variable.name: intervalType
variable.type: int_choice(Less than cutoff#Greater than cutoff#Between two cutoffs#Outside two cutoffs)

exercise.variable: Defines the minimum and maximum cutoff values (or the z-scores between which they ar randomly generated)
Variations can either request a probability of the expected number in n values
If the question is about the expected number in an interval, this should be positive. Otherwise leave it blank.

template.question: A normal distribution has mean #mu# = #mean(10)# and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd(3)#. What is the probability of getting a value #cut-offs(-3:3:1)#?

variation.question: The maximum daily temperature in a city in January is approximately normally distributed with mean #mu# = #mean[index](10,15,20,25)##degrees#C and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](3,4,5)##degrees#C.\\nWhat is the probability that the maximum temperature will be #cut-offs(-3:3:1)##degrees#C in one day?

The weight of a species of insect has a normal distribution with mean #mu# = #mean[index](18,19,20,21)# grams and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](1,1.5,2)# grams.\\nWhat is the probability that one insect has weight #cut-offs(-3:3:1)# grams?

The maximum daily temperature in a city in January is approximately normally distributed with mean #mu# = #mean[index](10,15,20,25)##degrees#C and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](3,4,5)##degrees#C.\\nIn how many days out of #count[](5,10,15,20,25,30)# would you expect the maximum temperature to be #cut-offs(-3:3:1)##degrees#C?

The weight of a type of insect has a normal distribution with mean #mu# = #mean[index](18,19,20,21)# grams and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](1,1.5,2)# grams.\\nHow many insects out of #count[](20,50,100,400)# would you expect would you expect to weigh #cut-offs(-3:3:1)# grams?

exercise.name: pFromTable
exercise.description: Find a normal probability using z-scores and a normal table
exercise.comment: A question asks for a probability about a normal distribution (or the expected count in a sample of n for some variations).\\nThe end-point(s) of the interval must be translated into z-scores first. A normal table is displayed for finding the probability from the z-scores.
exercise.option: Displays a simple template to help evaluate an expected count (not needed to find probabilities)
Requires interpolation between tabulated probabilities to get full marks.

variable.name: intervalType
variable.type: int_choice(Less than cutoff#Greater than cutoff#Between two cutoffs#Outside two cutoffs)

exercise.variable: Defines the minimum and maximum cutoff values (or the z-scores between which they ar randomly generated)
Variations can either request a probability of the expected number in n values
If the question is about the expected number in an interval, this should be positive. Otherwise leave it blank.

template.question: A normal distribution has mean #mu# = #mean(10)# and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd(3)#. What is the probability of getting a value #cut-offs(-3:3:1)#?

variation.question: The maximum daily temperature in a city in January is approximately normally distributed with mean #mu# = #mean[index](10,15,20,25)##degrees#C and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](3,4,5)##degrees#C.\\nWhat is the probability that the maximum temperature will be #cut-offs(-3:3:1)##degrees#C in one day?

The weight of a species of insect has a normal distribution with mean #mu# = #mean[index](18,19,20,21)# grams and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](1,1.5,2)# grams.\\nWhat is the probability that one insect has weight #cut-offs(-3:3:1)# grams?

The maximum daily temperature in a city in January is approximately normally distributed with mean #mu# = #mean[index](10,15,20,25)##degrees#C and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](3,4,5)##degrees#C.\\nIn how many days out of #count[](5,10,15,20,25,30)# would you expect the maximum temperature to be #cut-offs(-3:3:1)##degrees#C?

The weight of a type of insect has a normal distribution with mean #mu# = #mean[index](18,19,20,21)# grams and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](1,1.5,2)# grams.\\nHow many insects out of #count[](20,50,100,400)# would you expect would you expect to weigh #cut-offs(-3:3:1)# grams?

exercise.name: quantileByDraggingOverPdf
exercise.description: Find a normal quantile by dragging over its pdf
exercise.comment: The question asks for a value that is exceeded (or not reached) with a given probabiity.\\nThe normal pdf is shown and a vertical line can be dragged, showing the areas to the left and right.
exercise.option: Requires interpolation between tabulated probabilities to get full marks.
exercise.variable: Name for variable
Percentage of values in target interval
Template for the maximum possible x-value

template.question: A normal distribution has mean #mu# = #mean(10)# and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd(3)#. There is #percent(5:50)#% probability of getting a lower value than what x-value?

variation.question: The maximum daily temperature in a city in January is approximately normally distributed with mean #mu# = #mean[index](10,15,20,25)##degrees#C and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](3,4,5)##degrees#C.\\nWhat is the daily maximum temperature that will not be reached in #percent(5:50)#% of days?

The maximum daily temperature in a city in January is approximately normally distributed with mean #mu# = #mean[index](10,15,20,25)##degrees#C and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](3,4,5)##degrees#C.\\nWhat is the daily maximum temperature that will be exceeded in #percent(5:50)#% of days?

exercise.name: quantileByDraggingOverN(0,1)
exercise.description: Find a normal quantile by dragging over a N(0,1) pdf and translating z to x
exercise.comment: The question asks for a value that is exceeded (or not reached) with a given probabiity.\\nA N(0,1) pdf is shown and a vertical line can be dragged, showing the areas to the left and right. A template is provided to help translate the z-value to x.
exercise.variable: Name for variable
Percentage of values in target interval
Template for the maximum possible x-value

template.question: A normal distribution has mean #mu# = #mean(10)# and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd(3)#. There is #percent(5:50)#% probability of getting a lower value than what x-value?

variation.question: The maximum daily temperature in a city in January is approximately normally distributed with mean #mu# = #mean[index](10,15,20,25)##degrees#C and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](3,4,5)##degrees#C.\\nWhat is the daily maximum temperature that will not be reached in #percent(5:50)#% of days?

The maximum daily temperature in a city in January is approximately normally distributed with mean #mu# = #mean[index](10,15,20,25)##degrees#C and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](3,4,5)##degrees#C.\\nWhat is the daily maximum temperature that will be exceeded in #percent(5:50)#% of days?

exercise.name: quantile from tables
exercise.description: Find a normal quantile using normal tables and translating z to x
exercise.comment: The question asks for a value that is exceeded (or not reached) with a given probabiity.\\nA normal table is provided to find the appropriate z-score and a template helps translate the z-value to x.
exercise.variable: Name for variable
Percentage of values in target interval
Template for the maximum possible x-value

template.question: A normal distribution has mean #mu# = #mean(10)# and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd(3)#. There is #percent(5:50)#% probability of getting a lower value than what x-value?

variation.question: The maximum daily temperature in a city in January is approximately normally distributed with mean #mu# = #mean[index](10,15,20,25)##degrees#C and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](3,4,5)##degrees#C.\\nWhat is the daily maximum temperature that will not be reached in #percent(5:50)#% of days?

The maximum daily temperature in a city in January is approximately normally distributed with mean #mu# = #mean[index](10,15,20,25)##degrees#C and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](3,4,5)##degrees#C.\\nWhat is the daily maximum temperature that will be exceeded in #percent(5:50)#% of days?

exercise.name: mixedQns
exercise.description: Mixture of normal questions (prob, expected and quantile)
exercise.option: Requires some interpolation in the normal table for full marks (default gives full marks for an approximate answer)
exercise.variable: Name for variable

variable.name: intervalType
variable.type: int_choice(Less than cutoff#Greater than cutoff#Between two cutoffs#Outside two cutoffs#Less than cutoff, only cutoff value in qn#Greater than cutoff, only cutoff value in qn)

exercise.variable: Template for the maximum possible x-value
Defines the minimum and maximum cutoff values (or the z-scores between which they ar randomly generated)
If the question is about the expected number in an interval, this should be positive. Otherwise leave it blank.
Percentage of values in target interval

template.question: A normal distribution has mean #mu# = #mean(1.05)# and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd(0.02)#.\\n
template.ending: questionType(0)#What is the probability of a value less than #cut-offs(-3:-1:2)#?

variation.question: Bags of potatoes sold by a supermarket have weights that are normally distributed with mean #mu# = #mean[index](1.05,1.1,1.15,1.2)# kg and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](0.02,0.04,0.08)# kg.\\n
variation.ending: questionType(0)#The bags are labeled with weight #cut-offs(-3:-1:2)# kg. What is the probability that an individual bag will be underweight?
questionType(1)#If bags are labeled with weight #cut-offs(-2:-1:2)# kg, how many bags a sample of #count[](50,100,400)# would you expect to be underweight?
questionType(2)#What weight should be printed on the bag labels so that only #percent(2:10)#% of bags will be underweight?

variation.question: Bags of potatoes sold by a supermarket have weights that are normally distributed with mean #mu# = #mean[index](1.05,1.1,1.15,1.2)# kg and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](0.02,0.04,0.08)# kg.\\n
variation.ending: questionType(0)#The bags are labeled with weight #cut-offs(-3:-1:2)# kg. What is the probability that an individual bag will contain at least this weight of potatoes?
questionType(1)#If bags are labeled with weight #cut-offs(-2:-1:2)# kg, how many bags a sample of #count[](50,100,400)# are expected to contain at least this weight of potatoes?
questionType(2)#What weight should be printed on the bag labels so that #percent(90:98)#% of bags will contain at least this weight of potatoes?

variation.question: The weight of a species of insect has a normal distribution with mean #mu# = #mean[index](18,19,20,21)# grams and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](1,1.5,2)# grams.\\n
variation.ending: questionType(0)#What is the probability that an insect will weight #cut-offs(-3:3:1)# grams?
questionType(1)#How many insects in a sample of #count[](20,50,100,400)# would you expect to weigh #cut-offs(-3:3:1)# grams?
questionType(2)#percent(10:90)#% of insects will have weights #?:string[intervalType](less than*greater than)# how many grams?

variation.question: Student marks in a course are approximately normally distributed with mean #mu# = #mean[index](45,50,55,60)# and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](5,8,12)#.\\n
variation.ending: questionType(0)#If the pass mark for the course is set at #cut-offs(-2:0:0)#, what proportion of students is expected to pass the course?
questionType(1)#How many students in a class of #count[](20,50,100,400)# would you expect would you expect to get marks above #cut-offs(-3:3:1)#?
questionType(2)#What mark will be exceeded by #percent(10:90)#% of students?

variation.question: Student marks in a course are approximately normally distributed with mean #mu# = #mean[index](45,50,55,60)# and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd[](5,8,12)#.\\n
variation.ending: questionType(0)#If the pass mark for the course is set at #cut-offs(-2:0:0)#, what proportion of students is expected to fail the course?
questionType(1)#How many students in a class of #count[](20,50,100,400)# would you expect would you expect to get marks below #cut-offs(-3:3:1)#?
questionType(2)#How should the pass mark be set so that only #percent(4:15)#% of students fail?

exercise.name: pByCountingSdsFromMean
exercise.description: Find a normal probability based on 1, 2 or 3 sd from mean
exercise.variable: Name for variable
Used to generate the mean and SD for the normal distn
Determines z-scores for interval. Always leave as 0 to 19

template.question: A normal distribution has mean #mu# = #mean(:)# and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd(:)#.\\nWhat is the probability of a value #interval(:)#?

variation.question: Student marks in a course are approximately normally distributed with mean #mu# = #mean(:)# and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd(:)#.\\nWhat is the probability of a mark #interval(:)#?

The weight of a species of insect has a normal distribution with mean #mu# = #mean(:)# grams and standard deviation #sigma# = #sd(:)# grams.\\nWhat is the probability that a single insect's weight is #interval# grams?
